text:
It's never too late to learn about Judy Garland!

Judy Garland (born Josephine Garland) was a talented American actress and singer who mesmerized audiences with her incredible vocal range, energetic stage presence, and iconic film roles. Born on May 19, 1931, in Los Angeles, California, Garland grew up in a family of vaudeville performers. Her parents, Frank and Ethel Gumm, were both singers and musicians who encouraged their daughter's early talent.

Garland began her career as a child performer, singing and dancing with her sisters in a family act called The Gumm Sisters. After signing with MGM Studios, she made her film debut in 1939's "The Wizard of Oz" as Dorothy Gale, the plucky young heroine who won hearts with her rendition of "Over the Rainbow." This role catapulted her to stardom, and she went on to appear in numerous films, including "Babes in Arms" (1939), "Meet Me in St. Louis" (1944), and "A Star is Born" (1954).

Throughout her career, Garland's powerful, emotive voice and captivating stage presence earned her numerous accolades, including a Golden Globe Award and an Academy Award nomination. She was also a talented musician, releasing several successful albums and singles, including "Get Happy" and "The Trolley Song."

Despite her enduring success, Garland's personal life was marked by struggles with addiction and mental health. She was married five times and had three children, including Liza Minnelli, who followed in her mother's footsteps as a renowned performer.

Garland's legacy extends far beyond her film and recording work. She has been recognized as an icon of Hollywood's Golden Age, and her iconic songs, like "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," continue to inspire new generations of performers and fans.
